natural problem: What is the greatest common divisor of $2^{1001}-1$ and $2^{1012}-1$?
natural solution: By the Euclidean algorithm, \begin{align} &\text{gcd}\,(2^{1012}-1, 2^{1001}-1) \\ &\qquad= \text{gcd}\, (2^{1012}-1 - 2^{11}(2^{1001}-1), 2^{1001}-1) \\ &\qquad= \text{gcd}\,(2^{11}-1, 2^{1001}-1) \end{align} Using the divisibility rule for $11$, we know that $11$ divides into $1001$.
\] Thus $2^{1001}-1$ is divisible by $2^{11}-1$, so the greatest common divisor is $2^{11}-1 = \boxed{2047}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes gcd :: "(int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int)"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>a b. gcd a b = (if b = 0 then a else gcd b (a mod b))"
and h1 : "gcd ((2::int) powr 1001 - 1) ((2::int) powr 1012 - 1) = 2047"
shows  "2047 = (GREATEST a. \<exists>x y. gcd x y = a)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest common divisor of $2^{1001}-1$ and $2^{1012}-1$? The final Answer is 2047
 ### Proof
 By the Euclidean algorithm, \begin{align} &\text{gcd}\,(2^{1012}-1, 2^{1001}-1) \\ &\qquad= \text{gcd}\, (2^{1012}-1 - 2^{11}(2^{1001}-1), 2^{1001}-1) \\ &\qquad= \text{gcd}\,(2^{11}-1, 2^{1001}-1) \end{align} Using the divisibility rule for $11$, we know that $11$ divides into $1001$.
 Writing $2^{1001}$ as $(2^{11})^{91}$ and $1$ as $1^{91}$, we use the difference of odd powers factorization to find that   \[ 2^{1001} - 1 = (2^{11})^{91}-1^{91} = (2^{11}-1)((2^{11})^{90} + (2^{11})^{89}+\cdots (2^{11})^1 + 1).
 \] Thus $2^{1001}-1$ is divisible by $2^{11}-1$, so the greatest common divisor is $2^{11}-1 = \boxed{2047}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes gcd :: "(int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int)"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>a b. gcd a b = (if b = 0 then a else gcd b (a mod b))"
and h1 : "gcd ((2::int) powr 1001 - 1) ((2::int) powr 1012 - 1) = 2047"
shows  "2047 = (GREATEST a. \<exists>x y. gcd x y = a)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Determine the greatest common divisor (gcd) of $(2^{1001} - 1)$ and $(2^{1012} - 1)$ using the Euclidean algorithm (if $b = 0$ then $a$ else gcd $b (a \mod b)$). What is the greatest value that the gcd can take? The answer is $2047$.

a_1.formal problem:

fixes x y z :: nat
assumes h0 : "x = 2^1001 - 1"
and h1 : "y = 2^1012 - 1"
shows  "gcd x y = 2047"
a_1.formal solution:

 ### Proof
 By the Euclidean algorithm, \begin{align} &\text{gcd}\,(2^{1012}-1, 2^{1001}-1) \\ &\qquad= \text{gcd}\, (2^{1012}-1 - 2^{11}(2^{1001}-1), 2^{1001}-1) \\ &\qquad= \text{gcd}\,(2^{11}-1, 2^{1001}-1) \end{align} Using the divisibility rule for $11$, we know that $11$ divides into $1001$.
 Writing $2^{1001}$ as $(2^{11})^{91}$ and $1$ as $1^{91}$, we use the difference of odd powers factorization to find that   \[ 2^{1001} - 1 = (2^{11})^{91}-1^{91} = (2^{11}-1)((2^{11})^{90} + (2^{11})^{89}+\cdots (2^{11})^1 + 1).
 \] Thus $2^{1001}-1$ is divisible by $2^{11}-1$, so the greatest common divisor is $2^{11}-1 = \boxed{2047}$.
 *)

theorem 
fixes x y z :: nat
assumes h0 : "x = 2^1001 - 1"
and h1 : "y = 2^1012 - 1"
shows  "gcd x y = 2047"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

 *)
